explanation:
1) struct SHA1Context (full definition): Required to see the exact member types and any existing const-qualifiers for members referenced in SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (message_block, intermediate_hash, message_block_index). The MISRA check depends on whether the function mutates the pointed-to object(s) — if members are modified here but declared const in the struct (or vice versa), that changes whether the parameter or members should be const-qualified.

2) uint8_t / uint32_t typedefs (from <stdint.h>): Required to determine the precise element types of message_block and intermediate_hash (signedness/width). Knowing the exact types is necessary to reason about whether reads/writes in the function are modifying non-const objects and therefore whether the pointer could be const-qualified.

3) SHA1PadMessage prototype: This caller of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock is needed to inspect how the context is created/passed at call sites (e.g. whether callers treat context as const or non-const, or whether they cast away const). That affects the feasibility of changing parameter qualifiers and whether const propagation is possible.

4) SHA1Input prototype: Same reason as above — examine how SHA1ProcessMessageBlock is invoked elsewhere to determine whether making the parameter (or members) const would be compatible with call sites.

(Other items such as SHA1CircularShift are not required to decide pointer const-qualification because they do not take pointers to context.)
